image.altText: Rupert Murdoch, an older man with glasses, reads newspapers in the back of a car.

props.synopsis: His son Lachlan Murdoch will become the sole chair of News Corp following his decision to step down.

title.children: 'The time is right': Rupert Murdoch steps down as chairman of Fox Corporation and News Corp

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall sit, surrounded by their children, all the women holding bouquets

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch always wanted his media empire to stay in the family, but he could never commit to an heir. Despite having six children, only three were ever considered viable successors.

title.children: 'It's like The Godfather': How Rupert Murdoch's children spent their lives in competition

image.altText: A child wears a facemask and steers a boat on the water with the red-orange sky behind them.

props.synopsis: For the first time in three years, Australians face the risk of significant bushfires. Are we any better prepared for big fires than we were before Black Summer?

title.children: El Niño has ramped up bushfire risks again, but Australia's in a better place now than before Black Summer

image.altText: Police at a command post with crime scene tape across the front

props.synopsis: Police recover at least one body after fire destroys a home in Gnowangerup, in WA's Great Southern region.

title.children: Police recover body from house destroyed by fire in country WA

image.altText: A woman stands in a park wearing a dark denim jacket with a faint smile.

props.synopsis: An inquiry into price gouging in Australia has seen big business accused of using rising inflation to disguise their increasing profits while households struggle to make ends meet during a cost-of-living crisis.

title.children: Danielle works full-time as a nurse, but buying gifts for her nieces and nephews is a 'luxury' she can't afford

image.altText: A ribbon bound version of Australia's constitution with a photo of the Australian outback in the background.

props.synopsis: Australia will vote on whether to make a change to its constitution next month. But what is this document? And what is the proposed change? We break it down for you here, and show you what the constitution would look like if the Voice referendum is passed.

title.children: Here's how the Australian Constitution would change if the Voice referendum is passed

image.altText: Zelenskyy standing with US senators.

props.synopsis: After seeking to shore up international support at the United Nations, Mr Zelenskyy comes to Washington on a crosstown blitz including meetings with military leaders and Mr Biden and an evening address at the National Archives museum.

title.children: Zelenskyy meets with Biden amid some Republican skepticism over military aid

image.altText: Wind farms at dusk with the sun setting behind them on the coast line

props.synopsis: The debate still rages about dealing with climate change and, close to home, Australia's energy transition, which is under way but accompanied by increasing pain and problems, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Albanese government faces an uphill road and angry locals as it drives change to renewables

image.altText: Imran Khan walks through a dense crowd of men as he tries to leave a courtroom while wearing sunglasses.

props.synopsis: As former Pakistani prime minister Imran Khan languishes in a jail cell near Islamabad and his supporters fall silent in fear, his family welcomed the ABC inside his heavily guarded home in Lahore.

title.children: Cricket legend Imran Khan thought he could break the curse of Pakistani leaders. He was wrong

image.altText: Woman walks past entrance to London's Westminster Magistrates Court.

props.synopsis: Five Bulgarian nationals residing in the United Kingdom stand accused of "conspiring to collect information intended to be directly or indirectly useful to an enemy", and are due to face court next week.

title.children: British authorities approve charges against alleged Russian spies

image.altText: An illustrated image of Norman Bates with half his face as an android

props.synopsis: Five years after researchers created a psychopathic algorithm to demonstrate bias and discrimination in artificial intelligence, we're still learning its lessons.

title.children: 'Norman still haunts me': Why warnings from the world's first 'psychopath AI' are as relevant as ever

image.altText: An anxious-looking black Labrador curled up on a couch with a zebra-striped blanket.

props.synopsis: There's growing recognition that animals can develop mental and behavioural disorders like humans, but there are important factors to consider when treating these issues.

title.children: Prozac has helped Brian the labrador's anxiety. But treating pets' mental health can be complicated

image.altText: Julie Bishop speaks to the media

props.synopsis: A 24-year-old man is remanded in custody, charged with attempted murder and assault. The ANU says it was not given relevant information before the violent incident.

title.children: 'I was so angry': ANU chancellor Julie Bishop says university was in the dark ahead of stabbings

image.altText: Methamphetamine pictured next to pillows

props.synopsis: The men, including the grandson of a former WA Premier, were minor players in a plan to import $159 million worth of methamphetamine into Australia, a Perth court hears.

title.children: Three men were 'cannon fodder' in plot to import 99kg of meth hidden in latex pillows, court hears

image.altText: Gas plant infrastructure on a scrubby island at sunrise.

props.synopsis: American multinational Chevron says it will accept recommendations made by the Fair Work Commission to resolve a pay dispute between the company and unions at two of the world's largest gas projects in the Pilbara.

title.children: Chevron accepts Fair Work Commission recommendations to resolve pay dispute at company's Pilbara LNG plants

image.altText: A young man in an orange cap, at night, talking to media, with reflective light obscuring his face.

props.synopsis: Oscar Piastri is 11th in the drivers' championship, with six top 10 finishes and a best of fourth at the British Grand Prix.

title.children: Armed with upgrades and a new contract, Piastri sets sights on Japan

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in Melbourne's CBD

props.synopsis: The bosses of Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, NAB and ANZ descended on Canberra to defend shutting hundreds of regional bank branches in recent years. Here's how they justified their decisions after spending a day under the microscope.

title.children: It costs every Commonwealth Bank customer $40 to keep cash available — but the majority of them don't use it

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks at an out of focused Mark Butler.

props.synopsis: Week three of the referendum campaign and the PM found an excuse to return to Adelaide, where he announced a non-royal commission of inquiry into the handling of COVID. Many questions spring to mind, write Annabel Crabb and Brett Worthington.

title.children: It's been an eventful week in politics and for some reason it all comes back to ... Adelaide?

image.altText: Justin Trudeau shaking hands with Narendra Modi.

props.synopsis: The move comes after India warned nationals in Canada to exercise "caution" as ties between the two nations deteriorate.

title.children: India suspends visa services in Canada as tensions flare over killing of Sikh independence activist

image.altText: a woman in front of a sold sign out the front of an apartment block with a real estate agent

props.synopsis: Almost one in six sellers in Sydney's high-construction neighbourhoods are losing money, some as much as $100,000 for their lifetime investment, with interest rate squeeze pushing buyers to sell up for a loss.

title.children: Ella lost $100,000 when she sold her Sydney unit bought just five years ago — and she's not alone

image.altText: A close-up of a cage on the back of a police paddywagon.

props.synopsis: The Indigenous boy, who authorities have confirmed had done nothing wrong, was dragged kicking and screaming from a house and placed into the cage of the vehicle by police officers.

title.children: Inquiries triggered after 'distressed' 11-year-old placed into police paddy wagon in the NT

image.altText: Australian surfer Owen Wright covers his face as he is overcome by emotion after winning the Tahitit Pro while wearing a safety

props.synopsis: High-profile head injuries are forcing surfers to rethink the decades-old stigma around wearing helmets, particularly when taking on death-defying waves.

title.children: Surfing is one of the only extreme sports where helmets are rarely worn — but that's starting to change

image.altText: A man walking outside a courthouse while a female supporter shields her face.

props.synopsis: Raymond John O'Brien, 60, was jailed for five years over the December 2022 fire that caused more than $1 million damage.

title.children: Five years' jail for arsonist who doused staff member in petrol then set fire to real estate agency

image.altText: A heavily tattooed man sitting in a car, taking a selfie.

props.synopsis: Stanley Turvey had been a fugitive for hours when he crossed paths with an unwitting Melbourne man having a drink at a caravan park. As the investigation into his shooting death begins, here's a look at how the manhunt unfolded.

title.children: 'What are you doing mate?' Stranger reveals he shared a 'quiet beer' with man on the run

image.altText: Man leans on rural fire truck

props.synopsis: Pilot Grant Schultz was collecting water from a dam to fight a fire when the aircraft ditched into the water.

title.children: Pilot escapes with only 'inches of air' left as helicopter ditches into dam

image.altText: A colourful orange fish with neon blue filaments

props.synopsis: Flasher wrasse are popular aquarium fish known for their eye-catching courtship performances but an Australian Museum taxonomist says surprisingly little is known about those living in Australian waters.

title.children: Neon-coloured 'Amanda's flasher wrasse' the latest discovery from Australian Museum fish researcher

image.altText: Photo of a person holding up an Aboriginal flag. Behind it, out of foucs, is an even larger Aboriginal flag.

props.synopsis: More young and Indigenous Australians are enrolled to vote than ever before, as the Australian Electoral Commission prepares to begin early voting in remote communities next week.

title.children: More Indigenous Australians and young people registered to vote than ever before ahead of Voice referendum

image.altText: A man with glasses and a navy blue suit and tie stands behind a lecturn at a business conference

props.synopsis: In his first broadcast interview since ACCC allegations became public, Qantas chairman Richard Goyder maintains he has the confidence of the board and says major investors want him to stay.

title.children: 'We know we've let people down': Qantas chairman dodges calls to quit

image.altText: A family photo of a couple and two young children; a collapsed bridge

props.synopsis: The family's lawyers say nearby residents had repeatedly asked Google Maps to update its information for the "Bridge to Nowhere".

title.children: Google facing negligence lawsuit after GPS directions led man off collapsed bridge

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A respected religious leader from north-east Arnhem Land wants the No campaign to retract his image from its campaign material and publicly announce that it has done so.

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material
